title: From Correctness to Comprehension: AI Agents for Personalized Error Diagnosis in Education
author: Yi-Fan Zhang (National Laboratory of Pattern Recognition, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences), Hang Li (Michigan State University), Dingjie Song (CUHK-Shenzhen Natural Language Processing group), Lichao Sun (Lehigh University), Tianlong Xu (Squirrel Ai Learning group), Qingsong Wen (Squirrel Ai Learning group)
relevance_why: This paper explores a novel approach to personalized education that aligns with Haohe Liu's interest in applying machine learning frameworks to improve user interactions and learning experiences in domains such as audio and music.
background: The paper discusses the need for AI systems to not only evaluate correctness in student responses but also provide detailed error diagnosis and personalized feedback, which is critical in educational settings.
contribution: This paper introduces MathCCS to solve the challenge of error diagnosis in personalized education, achieving improved insights into students’ learning behaviors.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods focus largely on correctness metrics without providing constructive feedback or addressing individual learning paths.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by integrating historical performance data to provide tailored suggestions and track students’ learning trajectories.

key_innovation: The model leverages multi-agent collaboration to enhance error analysis by combining historical insights with real-time feedback.
real_world_impact: This framework can significantly enhance personalized learning experiences, potentially benefiting educational technologies and practices by offering adaptive learning paths.
limitations: The current model's accuracy in error classification and suggestion generation remains below human performance, indicating room for future improvement.

new_terms.Mathematical Classification and Construc: A benchmark designed to systematically analyze student errors and provide personalized feedback.
new_terms.Multi-Agent Collaborative Framework: A system architecture where multiple intelligent agents work together to analyze and diagnose student errors from different perspectives.
